cohere_generated_answer: Variations in atmospheric pressure, caused by the expansion of heated air and compression of cooled air, are the primary drivers of wind formation. Air moves from areas of high pressure to low pressure, resulting in wind. The Coriolis effect, caused by the Earth's rotation, influences the direction of wind, deflecting it to the right in the northern hemisphere and to the left in the southern hemisphere. The friction experienced by wind near the Earth's surface also affects its speed and direction. Atmospheric pressure variations are caused by the uneven distribution of temperature over the Earth's surface, with denser air near the surface having higher pressure. The vertical and horizontal distribution of pressure, along with the Coriolis force and friction, determine the velocity and direction of wind.
